prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For telling my girlfriend she has a deadline to start telling her friends we’re dating?
I feel I’m not the ass hole, but I’m open to have my mind changed. I ask because she seemed taken aback by my requirement got short/frustrated and didn’t say “I love you too” etc for the rest of our conversation before bed. #SayItback🔫 

I told her that if she can’t tell her friends by a certain date i don’t think it’s going to work between us anymore 

Important note - we’re long distance  

We’ve been dating in total for 3 years. Had a small break up during my first deployment a year and a half in, but got back together shortly after. She told her friends that we split, but never that we were back together. We’ve been back together for over a year now. She took a while to tell her family, but her friends still don’t know.  
Her solution to this is that “I’ve told my friends I’m not dating ANYONE” or when I was in town and her friends asked if we talked “yeah I saw him we talked”

People suggested to just drop her because it’s not cool, but after 3 years together I want to give it a chance for her to fix it. 
I’ve been pretty frustrated about this for a while. I want to take pictures together and make a new profile pic, and so that her friends know not to get with her, as I told her the above doesn’t cut it for me. There should be no reason to hide it unless you’ve got something to hide, right? After I said this she immediately turned it on me and accused me of lying about unrelated things, saying “I don’t know if you’re doing xxx thing or going to parties without telling me, so I just have to trust you just like you need to trust me” 
All my friends know we’re dating, that’s a key difference. 

"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the author told his girlfriend she has a deadline to tell her friends they're dating, otherwise it won't work. They're in a long-distance relationship, 3 years together, had a breakup during a deployment but got back together. She hasn't told her friends, just said she told them she's not dating anyone, and when asked about the author, she says they talk. He wants her to be open with her friends, and when he set a deadline, she got upset and turned the argument on him.

Hmm. First, I need to consider the dynamics of long-distance relationships. It's harder because you can't be physically present, so communication and trust are key. The author feels that her friends not knowing they're dating is a problem. He wants her to be open, which is understandable. But setting a deadline and ultimatums can be a big deal. 

The girlfriend's approach of saying she's not dating anyone might be her way of protecting her privacy, but the author sees it as hiding. Long-distance can make trust issues worse. The fact that he's open with his friends but she's not might create an imbalance. However, setting a deadline might come off as controlling. 

Also, when he mentioned the deadline, she reacted by accusing him of lying about unrelated things. That could mean she felt attacked and is deflecting. But the author is frustrated because he wants her to be public about their relationship. 

Is he in the wrong? Well, he's trying to address a legitimate concern—transparency in the relationship. But maybe the way he did it was harsh. Ultimatums can be stressful. On the other hand, she's been avoiding this for a long time. Maybe both have some responsibility. But the question is if the author is in the wrong. 

The key points: long-distance, 3 years, she hasn't told her friends, he wants openness. He set a deadline, she reacted negatively. He's not the one hiding, he's trying to get her to be honest. But the deadline might be too rigid. However, it's his right to set boundaries. So maybe he's not in the wrong. Answer B.
